pr_title: [RW-3389] [RW-4125] [risk=no] Speed up user admin table load time & refresh the UI

timeline.bodyText: I tend to prefer method  references  where possible, i.e. profileMapper::adminViewToModel. additionally,  you can  declare List<AdminTableUser> adminViewsToModels(Collection<DbUser> dbUsers); in the mapper and use that. The code isn't as pretty, but it uses a pre-allocated list for the result.
timeline.author: jaycarlton
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -459,51 +455,9 @@ public void validateNewProfile(Profile profile) throws BadRequestException {
     validateProfileForCorrectness(dummyProfile, profile);
   }
 
-  // Get all the profiles. Best we can do without surgery on the entity classes is to do one query
-  // per table and join them in code.

-    // A user may have signed the TOS many times. Pick only the latest.

-                        e.getValue().stream()
-                            .max(Comparator.comparing(DbUserTermsOfService::getAgreementTime))
-                            .orElse(
-                                null))); // not reachable since  Multimaps.index() will always give
-    // a non-empty value set
-
-    // The cached free tier usage aka total cost for each user, by ID

-
-    final Map<Long, Double> userIdToQuota =
-        usersHeavy.stream()
-            .collect(
-                ImmutableMap.toImmutableMap(
-                    DbUser::getUserId, freeTierBillingService::getUserFreeTierDollarLimit));
-
-    return usersHeavy.stream()
-        .map(
-            dbUser ->
-                profileMapper.toModel(
-                    dbUser,
-                    userIdToAffiliationModel.get(dbUser.getUserId()),
-                    userIdToMostRecentTos.get(dbUser.getUserId()),
-                    userIdToFreeTierUsage.get(dbUser.getUserId()),
-                    userIdToQuota.get(dbUser.getUserId())))
+  public List<AdminTableUser> listAllProfiles() {
+    return userDao.getAdminTableUsers().stream()
+        .map(dbUser -> profileMapper.adminViewToModel(dbUser))

timeline.bodyText:
asiide: I was fooling around with BigQuery yesterday and came up with what I thought was a reasonable way to break down the monolith of columns in the user table. It might make sense for our API as well (particularly if types like this could reuse things like the compliance section), though you'd have to add mapping annotations in MapStruct.
Another advantage would be reusing descriptions for fields and keeping types in sync (e.g. if we changed userId to int32).
timeline.author: jaycarlton

Oh interesting!  I didn't know you could set fields using this approach.
👍 to projection interface generally.
timeline.author: jmthibault79

replies.bodyText: Yeah, I learned this when I realized I needed to create some mock data for testing. Adding setters to the interface and using Spring's SpelAwareProxyProjectionFactory was a convenient way to do this.

timeline.bodyText: I'd like a name that indicates that this is the list of bypassed modules for the user - maybe getBypassedModules() ?

timeline.bodyText: What happens when this value is not present?
timeline.author: jmthibault79

replies.bodyText: Good catch – fixed with some explicit empty string handling.
replies.author: gjuggler

timeline.author: jmthibault79

replies.bodyText: I thought so too, but it's a required prop.
replies.author: gjuggler

timeline.bodyText:
I'm not familiar with how filtering works in a DataTable.  What happens to Columns like this with neither "exclude" nor "match" ?
Really excellent feature addition btw
timeline.author: jmthibault79

replies.bodyText:
I think all columns are included by default. So we'll match on name, institution, username, and contact email. My feeling is that filtering should "just work" without having to explain too much to users... if we need to index more fields for searching, or remove columns, we can do that over time.
Agree re: it being a nice addition – this is a very good reason to use well-developed community components, to save us the time of building advanced functionality like this. I found myself thinking about this as I dug deeper into PopupTrigger, which appears to be built more or less from scratch. It has no tests, and no documentation... which just makes it frustrating to work with as a core UI component.
replies.author: gjuggler

timeline.bodyText: Note: most of the changes in this file are related to fixing the RW-4125 bug (re-sorting admin table breaks bypass actions). I had wanted to split this out into its own PR, but the change from Profile --> AdminTableUser made it hard to cleanly extract. Accept my apologies in advance :)
timeline.author: gjuggler

timeline.bodyText: This is the crux of the fix in this file. Whenever a new user is passed in via props, we want to reset the "default" set of access modules selected. This causes the pop-up to show the correct set of "active" modules corresponding to the user.
timeline.author: gjuggler

timeline.bodyText: n.b. this is how we achieve the "horizontally scrollable but with fixed column" effect. There's a bit of manual column width-setting required to make sure the fixed 200px lines up correctly.
timeline.author: gjuggler
jmthibault79

timeline.message: Add a projection for the admin user table and refresh the UI.
Fix user bypass bug and address some comments
Fix bypass bugs and add loading spinner.
